columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value of a new plant for a company based on three financing options.

The net present value (NPV) of a company refers to the present value of a company's cash flow based on its required rate of return. This measures the return on investment of a particular project. A positive NPV means that the project is profitable while a negative NPV tells otherwise.

Before we start solving the net present value of the new plant, we will first list down the given values that will be used in solving. 


|Target debt-equity ratio |0.60 | 
|--|--| 
| Cost of new plant|$65,000,000 | 
| Expected aftertax cash flow|$9,400,000 | 
| Flotation cost of common stock|8% | 
| Required return on equity|14% | 
| Coupon rate|8% | 
|New issue of bond |at par | 
| Flotation cost of new bonds|4% | 
| Tax rate|21% |

Now that we have the given values, we can now start solving for the net present value of this new plant. 

In order to do this, we will first solve for the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The WACC of a company refers to the average cost of capital of the firm from all sources such as common stock, bonds, and preferred stock among others. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\dfrac{\text{Equity}}{\text{Equity}+\text{Debt}}\times \text{Cost of Equity}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{Debt}}{\text{Equity}+\text{Debt}}\\
&\times \left( \dfrac{\text{Long-term debt}}{\text{Long-term debt}+\text{Accounts payable}} \times \text{Cost of long-term debt}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})+ \dfrac{\text{Accounts payable}}{\text{Accounts payable}+\text{Long-term debt}} \times \text{WACC}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

From the formula above, we can simply substitute the given values to get the weighted average cost of capital for the new plant.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}&=\dfrac{1}{1+0.60} \times 0.14
\\
&+\dfrac{0.60}{1+0.60}\\
&\times\left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.15}\times 0.08 \times (1-0.21)+\dfrac{0.15}{1+0.15}\times \text{WACC}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown variable on one side  then simplify:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{WACC}-0.48913125\times\text{WACC}&=0.1081086875\\[15 pt]
\dfrac{0.51086875\times \text{WACC}}{0.51086875}&=\dfrac{0.1081086875}{0.51086875}\\[15 pt]
\text{WACC}&=0.21162
\end{aligned}$$

The weighted average cost of capital of the company is $0.21162$.

Now that we have this value, we can solve for the net present value using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=\dfrac{\text{Aftertax cash flow}}{\text{WACC}}-\text{}\text{Cost of new plant}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$9,400,000}{0.21162}-\$65,000,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$44,419,242.04-\$65,000,000\\[15 pt]
&=-\$20,580,757.96
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the new plant is $-\$20,580,757.96$ which means that it is not profitable.
